Does the graphic tablet really help in drawing so they could alternative to mouse and keyboard?
I would have to say yes, well I mean.
It really depends on how you work.
I mean, for me, yes, I mean, I was doing keyboard and mouse art for years before I got my first tablet and he difference was phenomenal.
I was able to do a lot more detail.
I was able to and it also really reinvigorated my interest in digital art because there was such a bar with using the keyboard and mouse with the things I wanted to do and how I wanted to do them.
And I want to qualify that because I mean some people they never, they don't need a tablet.
There's a lettering artist that I follow Jessica she, she really prefers keyboard and mouse for her digital work.
And she's doing a lot of vector work with letters and designs like that.
So it really depends on what you're doing and what you want to accomplish.
If the tablet is a good fit for you.
But for me personally, I.
Really enjoy traditional art and drawing in that way and I was not able to bridge the gap.
I wasn't able to draw down here and look up here.
It was very, very difficult for me, but as soon as I combine those two and was able to draw down here and look here, that just kind of changed the broader, closer traditional illustration for me.
An really helped me advance my skills.
But again, I think that answer is based on what you're trying to accomplish.
If the tablet is a good fit for you or not.
If you're doing a lot of graphic design work annuar in illustrator for lettering and all that stuff.
When I do graphic design work, I'm amazingly like keyboard and mouse again, so it switches over so my workspaces designed to allow me to do both.
I can push this out-of-the-way use keyboard and mouse do writing if I need to an.
And not be, you know, have everything crowding in at once.
But I can say personally that the tablet really changed a lot of things for me.
It helps me speed up.
It helped me because originally I would take several days to do one web comic and I would be, you know, keyboard mouse drawing out every single thing.
Things that take me a lot less time now to do.

So like for example, I would use the pen tool and the width tool to give line variance something that I do now is just a stroke and the blob brush tool and I can create these more sketchy doughy lines when I could with the with the pen tool.
So for me it was a game changer, but for you it may not be or it maybe you just have to sit down and be honest with yourself.
Say what am I trying to accomplish?
And what is the work that I really love doing?
And it's just a tool that will help me.
'cause in the end it's all a tool.
I mean this is nothing that you know.
Your basics are what's going to make your art.
Advance, you know if you're studying.
If you're studying lettering.
If you're studying anatomy.
If you're studying, you know the fundamentals, composition, values, and all of that.
That is what you're going to advance quickly with more so than changing up any tools, and that's why you gotta keep in mind too.
It's not an answer to make your art better, it's an answer to accelerate.

I mean, the big difference between illustrator and Photoshop is illustrators vector program.
What that means is it's based.
Everything you draw is based off of mathematics, so you could blow up anything you got in here to the size of a billboard or shrink it down to a postage stamp.
You will have no loss of clarity because it's just it's multiplying numbers and you've got.
Um?
You're not bound to settings like in Photoshop, which is of raster program.
You're kind of set, you know, a lot of artists.

They will start, they'll start off with a low res file, will get a lot of work done, and then they'll bump it up to 300 DPI if they want to go for print, you kind of have to do a little bit more file or thinking and press around your your work when your work.
When you're working in Photoshop, you've got to think about OK.
am I only going to use this for web?
am I going to use this for?
Print do I want to make it high res enough in case they want to do for print an then you gotta set up your file to potentially be.
Workable in those final situations like those print situations, but I remember a lot of single lot.
You know, starting out with the 72 DPI which is screen rise and then bumping it up once you get closer to the final product of 300 and filling things in.
It really as far as you know, prep in working on my end.
I really like the fact that I just draw it once and I don't have to really worry.
Aside from, you know.
Like Orientation and stuff like that I don't have to worry about, you know, is this going to look good on 11 by 17 is just going to look good printed 24 by 36.
I know the answer is yes because this can be scaled up and down indefinitely.
You may not have that versatility unless you think about it as you're going into it with a raster designed illustration.
But again, you know a lot of people that are doing it professionally.
They just they have those things set up and ready to go and.
They're designing with that end in mind anyway, so it really is what you're used to.
If there is a learning curve for illustrator, there's a learning curve.
Really for any program, but I think Photoshop, probably for drawing purposes, especially with all the brushes and things you have available as closer, maybe to traditional art.
But I started out in um, using vectors, doing a lot of keyboard and mouse drawing, and so this is the program that I know best and I'm fastest in, so that's what I've always stuck with.
And plus I love that I can take any of these guys.
And, you know, do whatever I want with them and the file back when file size mattered a lot, I would create.
Add files and they would be a fraction of the size of a.

You know a TIF file that I would have to send out an the TIF file could take 40 to 50 minutes to transfer, whereas you know two to four MB illustrator file just goes lickety split so that was another thing that kind of pushed me towards working illustrator a lot more than photo shop was.
